elements.content: We report herein a novel infinite two-dimensional water morphology, found in a metallo-organic host, made up of discrete cyclic water hexamers and which contains large circular holes defined by 18 molecules of water.
elements.clean_text: We report herein a novel infinite two-dimensional water morphology, found in a metallo-organic host, made up of discrete cyclic water hexamers and which contains large circular holes defined by 18 molecules of water.

elements.content: We report herein a novel infinite two-dimensional water morphology, found in a metallo-organic host, made up of discrete water hexamers and which contains large circular holes defined by 18 molecules of water.
elements.clean_text: We report herein a novel infinite two-dimensional water morphology, found in a metallo-organic host, made up of discrete water hexamers and which contains large circular holes defined by 18 molecules of water.

elements.content: In recent years, the theoretical and experimental study of small water clusters became relevant since they are the first step toward understanding the behavior of bulk water. Several water clusters found in organic or metallo-organic crystal hosts have been structurally characterized. However, very little is known about how these clusters link themselves to form larger networks of water molecules, which structurally lie between small water clusters and bulk water. Very recently, significant progress has been made with respect to the structural characterization of one-dimensional (1D) aggregates such as water chains and tapes. In contrast, there are very few examples of two- or three-dimensional (2D or 3D) water polymers. The structural elucidation of these novel water morphologies is important to gain insight into some of the unexplained properties of water, into the processes that occur at the ice−liquid, ice−air, and liquid−air interfaces, and into the nature of water−water and water−solute interactions.
elements.clean_text: In recent years, the theoretical and experimental study of small water clusters became relevant since they are the first step toward understanding the behavior of bulk water. Several water clusters found in organic or metallo-organic crystal hosts have been structurally characterized. However, very little is known about how these clusters link themselves to form larger networks of water molecules, which structurally lie between small water clusters and bulk water. Very recently, significant progress has been made with respect to the structural characterization of one-dimensional (1D) aggregates such as water chains and tapes. In contrast, there are very few examples of two- or three-dimensional (2D or 3D) water polymers. The structural elucidation of these novel water morphologies is important to gain insight into some of the unexplained properties of water, into the processes that occur at the ice-liquid, ice-air, and liquid-air interfaces, and into the nature of water-water and water-solute interactions.

elements.content: To our knowledge, all the 2D water polymers reported previously are associations of small cyclic water clusters fused by “edge-sharing” and without discontinuities in their structures. We describe herein a novel water morphology, a 2D holed polymer, observed in the crystalline solid ∞ 2[Cu(Hmal)(4pds)]·6H2O (1) (4pds:  4,4‘-dipyridyl disulfide; Hmal2-:  dianion of malic acid).
elements.clean_text: To our knowledge, all the 2D water polymers reported previously are associations of small cyclic water clusters fused by "edge-sharing" and without discontinuities in their structures. We describe herein a novel water morphology, a 2D holed polymer, observed in the crystalline solid ∞ 2[Cu(Hmal)(4pds)]⋅6H2O (1) (4pds: 4,4‘-dipyridyl disulfide; Hmal2-: dianion of malic acid).

elements.content: Compound 1 was prepared at room temperature by slow diffusion of an ethanol solution of 4pds into an aqueous solution containing copper(II) malate in a 1:1 molar ratio. Single-crystal diffraction analysis revealed that 1 contains one 4pds ligand, one Cu2+, one Hmal2- anion, and six water molecules in the asymmetric unit (Figure ). Each copper(II) ion is six-coordinated by two pyridine nitrogen atoms from two 4pds ligand units, and by four oxygen atoms from two Hmal2- anions, in an axially elonged [4+1+1] octahedral geometry. The elongations of these Cu−O bonds [Cu−O5 2.287(6) and Cu−O4 2.683(6) Å] may be ascribed to the Jahn Teller effect. The Cu2+ ions are linked by 4pds moieties along the a-axis, forming zigzag chains [d(Cu2+-4pds-Cu2+_1) = 10.676(3) Å, symmetry code 1:  1 + x, y, z]. These chains are transversally joined by the Hmal2- anions [d(Cu2+-Hmal2--Cu2+_1) = 5.861(2) Å, symmetry code 1:  1/2 − x, −1/2 + y, 5/2 − z]. The α-hydroxycarboxylate moiety of the Hmal2- ligand chelates one copper(II) ion, while the remaining carboxylate group acts as bridge between two neighboring metal centers. Therefore, the global structure should be described as a 2D coordination polymer that grows along the ab-plane (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: Compound 1 was prepared at room temperature by slow diffusion of an ethanol solution of 4pds into an aqueous solution containing copper(II) malate in a 1:1 molar ratio. Single-crystal diffraction analysis revealed that 1 contains one 4pds ligand, one Cu2+, one Hmal2- anion, and six water molecules in the asymmetric unit (Figure ). Each copper(II) ion is six-coordinated by two pyridine nitrogen atoms from two 4pds ligand units, and by four oxygen atoms from two Hmal2- anions, in an axially elonged [4+1+1] octahedral geometry. The elongations of these Cu-O bonds [Cu-O5 2.287(6) and Cu-O4 2.683(6) Å] may be ascribed to the Jahn Teller effect. The Cu2+ ions are linked by 4pds moieties along the a-axis, forming zigzag chains [d(Cu2+-4pds-Cu2+_1) = 10.676(3) Å, symmetry code 1: 1 + x, y, z]. These chains are transversally joined by the Hmal2- anions [d(Cu2+-Hmal2--Cu2+_1) = 5.861(2) Å, symmetry code 1: 1/2 - x, -1/2 + y, 5/2 - z]. The α-hydroxycarboxylate moiety of the Hmal2- ligand chelates one copper(II) ion, while the remaining carboxylate group acts as bridge between two neighboring metal centers. Therefore, the global structure should be described as a 2D coordination polymer that grows along the ab-plane (Figure ).

elements.content: Ball-and-stick representations of the asymmetric unit (top) and of a “PL” sheet of the 2D coordination polymer (bottom) found in the crystal cell of1. Water molecules and hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes, 1:  x − 1, y, z and 2:  −x + 1/5, y − 1/2, −z + 5/2.
elements.clean_text: 1  Ball-and-stick representations of the asymmetric unit (top) and of a "PL" sheet of the 2D coordination polymer (bottom) found in the crystal cell of1. Water molecules and hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes, 1: x - 1, y, z and 2: -x + 1/5, y - 1/2, -z + 5/2.

elements.content: There are two classes of 2D coordination polymers in 1. One of them is constituted by M enantiomers of the 4dps ligand and d-enantiomers of the Hmal2- anion (“MD” sheets). The other one is formed by P-4dps and L-Hmal2- ligands (“PL” sheets). These “PL” and “MD” chiral sheets are disposed in an alternate sequence in the crystal cell of 1 that, consequently, has an achiral nature.
elements.clean_text: There are two classes of 2D coordination polymers in 1. One of them is constituted by M enantiomers of the 4dps ligand and d-enantiomers of the Hmal2- anion ("MD" sheets). The other one is formed by P-4dps and L-Hmal2- ligands ("PL" sheets). These "PL" and "MD" chiral sheets are disposed in an alternate sequence in the crystal cell of 1 that, consequently, has an achiral nature.

elements.content: The hydrogen-bonding association of lattice water molecules in 1 leads to the formation of cyclic hexamers with a “puckered-boat” conformation (Figure ). The average O···O distance in the hexamer is 2.78 Å. This distance is shorter than those observed in liquid water (2.85 Å)16 and comparable to the corresponding value in hexagonal ice (I h) (2.76 Å). Moreover, the average O···O···O angle is 107.3°, slightly shorter than the corresponding value of 109.3° in I h.
elements.clean_text: The hydrogen-bonding association of lattice water molecules in 1 leads to the formation of cyclic hexamers with a "puckered-boat" conformation (Figure ). The average O⋅⋅⋅O distance in the hexamer is 2.78 Å. This distance is shorter than those observed in liquid water (2.85 Å)16 and comparable to the corresponding value in hexagonal ice (I h) (2.76 Å). Moreover, the average O⋅⋅⋅O⋅⋅⋅O angle is 107.3°, slightly shorter than the corresponding value of 109.3° in I h.

elements.content: Ball representation of the “puckered-boat” hexameric water clusters (in blue) found in the crystal cell of1. The red balls are water molecules belonging to neighboring water hexamers. Symmetry codes 2:  3/2 − x, 1/2 + y, 1/2 − z and 4:  1/2 + x, 3/2 + y, 1/2 + z.
elements.clean_text: 2  Ball representation of the "puckered-boat" hexameric water clusters (in blue) found in the crystal cell of1. The red balls are water molecules belonging to neighboring water hexamers. Symmetry codes 2: 3/2 - x, 1/2 + y, 1/2 - z and 4: 1/2 + x, 3/2 + y, 1/2 + z.

elements.content: Each water cluster is connected to other three identical hexamers by hydrogen bonding (Figure ). The interhexamer water−water connections have an average O···O distance of 2.998 Å. The water clusters do not share any water molecules with their neighbors:  they are discrete moieties. The aggregation of the hexamers is controlled by an unprecedented “vertex-connected” association mode, in contrast with previously reported water associations where clusters are always fused by “edge-sharing”. This novel cluster aggregation mode leads to formation of a corrugated 2D framework of water molecules along the bc-plane (Figure ). Interestingly, the water sheets are not continuous and contain large circular holes defined by 18 molecules of water. The average diameter of these gaps is 11.76 Å. It must to be noted that the cavity dimensions described here are crystallographic scalar quantities only and do not take into account the van der Waals radii of the atoms defining the cavity. The water sheets are piled along the a-axis of the crystal cell, forming cylindrical water channels. The minimum O···O distance between two water sheets is 3.44 Å. To our knowledge, this is the first example of a 2D water polymer containing holes in its structure, that is, a 2D holed water polymer.
elements.clean_text: Each water cluster is connected to other three identical hexamers by hydrogen bonding (Figure ). The interhexamer water-water connections have an average O⋅⋅⋅O distance of 2.998 Å. The water clusters do not share any water molecules with their neighbors:  they are discrete moieties. The aggregation of the hexamers is controlled by an unprecedented "vertex-connected" association mode, in contrast with previously reported water associations where clusters are always fused by "edge-sharing". This novel cluster aggregation mode leads to formation of a corrugated 2D framework of water molecules along the bc-plane (Figure ). Interestingly, the water sheets are not continuous and contain large circular holes defined by 18 molecules of water. The average diameter of these gaps is 11.76 Å. It must to be noted that the cavity dimensions described here are crystallographic scalar quantities only and do not take into account the van der Waals radii of the atoms defining the cavity. The water sheets are piled along the a-axis of the crystal cell, forming cylindrical water channels. The minimum O⋅⋅⋅O distance between two water sheets is 3.44 Å. To our knowledge, this is the first example of a 2D water polymer containing holes in its structure, that is, a 2D holed water polymer.

elements.content: Top, ball representation of the 2D holed water polymer found in1. The diameter of the 18-membered water holes has an average value of 11.76 Å. The corrugated water sheets are piled along the a-axis of the crystal cell (bottom).
elements.clean_text: 3  Top, ball representation of the 2D holed water polymer found in1. The diameter of the 18-membered water holes has an average value of 11.76 Å. The corrugated water sheets are piled along the a-axis of the crystal cell (bottom).

elements.content: The 2D holed water network is interpenetrated with the metallo-organic host. The 4pds ligands of the coordination polymer pass through the holes of the water network, whereas the [Cu(Hmal)] n chains are disposed in the space between two water sheets (Figure ). There are two 4pds ligand units, belonging to two different sheets of the 2D coordination polymer, in each water hole. The planes of the water polymer and of the metallo-organic network are inclined one with respect to the other (Figure ), forming an angle of 85°. There is an unique class of connection between both polymers. The O1 atom of the Hmal2- ligand is hydrogen bonded [O1w···O1_1 = 2.84(2) Å, symmetry code 1:  3/2 − x, −1/2 + y, 3/2 − z] to one water molecule of a cyclic hexamer (Figure ). Consequently, the overall structure could be considered as a 3D metallo-supramolecular network (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: The 2D holed water network is interpenetrated with the metallo-organic host. The 4pds ligands of the coordination polymer pass through the holes of the water network, whereas the [Cu(Hmal)] n  chains are disposed in the space between two water sheets (Figure ). There are two 4pds ligand units, belonging to two different sheets of the 2D coordination polymer, in each water hole. The planes of the water polymer and of the metallo-organic network are inclined one with respect to the other (Figure ), forming an angle of 85°. There is an unique class of connection between both polymers. The O1 atom of the Hmal2- ligand is hydrogen bonded [O1w⋅⋅⋅O1_1 = 2.84(2) Å, symmetry code 1: 3/2 - x, -1/2 + y, 3/2 - z] to one water molecule of a cyclic hexamer (Figure ). Consequently, the overall structure could be considered as a 3D metallo-supramolecular network (Figure ).

elements.content: Part of the unit cell of1, exhibiting the unique class of hydrogen-bonding interactions between the water net and the coordination polymer.
elements.clean_text: 4  Part of the unit cell of1, exhibiting the unique class of hydrogen-bonding interactions between the water net and the coordination polymer.

elements.content: (a) Part of the unit cell of1, exhibiting the interpenetration between the metallo-organic and the water 2D polymers. Red and cyan colors represent “MD” and “PL” metallo-organic sheets, respectively. There are two [Cu(4pds)Cu] units, belonging to two different metallo-organic sheets, in each water hole. (b) Illustration of the interpenetration mode from the ab-plane of the crystal cell of 1. (c) Schematic view of the interpenetration mode between both polymers from the ac-plane.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Part of the unit cell of1, exhibiting the interpenetration between the metallo-organic and the water 2D polymers. Red and cyan colors represent "MD" and "PL" metallo-organic sheets, respectively. There are two [Cu(4pds)Cu] units, belonging to two different metallo-organic sheets, in each water hole. (b) Illustration of the interpenetration mode from the ab-plane of the crystal cell of 1. (c) Schematic view of the interpenetration mode between both polymers from the ac-plane.

elements.content: In conclusion, a novel infinite 2D water framework made up of discrete cyclic water hexamers has been structurally characterized. To our knowledge, this is the first example of a 2D holed water polymer. We believe this water assembly brings to light a novel mode of the cooperative association of water molecules and enhances the understanding of the 2D structural aspects of bulk water.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, a novel infinite 2D water framework made up of discrete cyclic water hexamers has been structurally characterized. To our knowledge, this is the first example of a 2D holed water polymer. We believe this water assembly brings to light a novel mode of the cooperative association of water molecules and enhances the understanding of the 2D structural aspects of bulk water.

metadata.title:
Supramolecular Aggregation of Hexameric Water Clusters into a 2D Water
Polymer Containing (H2O)18 Holes
